page.title: .addAfter() - Minified.js
page.main:
back to Overview

.addAfter()

Inserts the given text or element(s) as sibling after each element of this list.

Syntax Variants

$(selector).addAfter(text)
$(selector).addAfter(factoryFunction)
$(selector).addAfter(list)
$(selector).addAfter(node)

Parameters

text
a string to add as text node of the list elements
factoryFunction
a function(listItem, listIndex) that will be invoked for each list element to create the nodes. The function can return either a string for a text node, a function to invoke, an HTML element or a list containing strings, lists, functions and/or DOM nodes.
list
a list containing text, functions, nodes or more list. Please note that if you have DOM nodes in this list and attempt to add them to more than one element, the result is undefined. You should always use factories if your Minified list contains more than one item.
node
a DOM node to add only to the first element of the list.
(return value)
the current list

Description

Inserts the given text or element(s) as sibling after each element of this list. If a string has been given, it will be added as text node. If you pass a function, it will be invoked for each list element to create the node(s) to add. It can return all values allowed by addAfter(), including another function to be called. If you pass a list or a function returns a list, all its elements will be added using the rules above.

It is also possible to pass a DOM node, but it will be added only to the first element of the list, because DOM does not allow adding it more than once.

Example

Using the following HTML: 

<div>
  
Here is some text

</div>
Use addAfter() with a simple string to add a text node. 
$('#mainText').addAfter('Disclaimer: bla bla bla');
This results in the following HTML: 
<div>
  
Here is some text

  Disclaimer: bla bla bla
</div>

Example

You can also pass an Element Factory: 

$('#mainText').addAfter(EE('span', {'className': 'disclaimer'}, 'Disclaimer: bla bla bla'));
With the previous example's HTML, this would create this: 
<div>
  
Disclaimer: bla bla bla

  <span class="disclaimer">WARNING</span>
</div>
